LEARNING HARMONIZED REPRESENTATIONS FOR
SPECULATIVE SAMPLING
Lefan Zhang, Xiaodan Wang, Yanhua Huang! Ruiwen Xo
Xiaohongshu Ine
Shanghai, China
{lotan, xiavdan?, yanhuahuang, ruiweneu}@xiachongshu. com
ABSTRACT
Speculative sampling is a promising approach to accelerate the decoding stage
for Large Language Models (LLMs) Recent advancements that leverage target
LILM’s contextual information, such as hidden states and KV cache, have shown:
significant prachcal improvements. However, these approaches suffer from isco.
sistent context between traning and decoding. We also observe another discrep-
ancy between the training and decoding objectives in existing speculate sam.
phog methods. In this work, we propase a solution named HArmonized Specu
lative Sampling (HASS) that learns harmonized representations to address these
issues. HASS accelerates the decoding stage without adding infereace overhead
through harmonized objective distillation and harmonized context alignment. Ex.
perments on four LLaMA models demonstrate that HASS achieves 2811-4 05
wall-clock time speedup ratio averaging across three datasets, surpassing EAGLE-
2 by 8%-20%
1 INTRODUCTION
Generative Large Language Models (11.Ms), such as GPT-4 (Achiam et al, 2023) and LL aMA (Tou
vron et al, 2023), have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across a wide range of tasks Never
theless, efficiently decoding from these models poses a significant challenge due to the inherent
auto-regressive decoding mechanism, which restncts ther applicability in Ume-sensitive scenanas.
Speculative sampling (Chen et al, 2023, Leviathan et al, 2023) offers a solution by leveraging addi.
hhonal resources to increase concurrency. Specifically, itemploys an efficient draft model to generate
draft tokens auto-regressively, which are thea concurrently ventied by the target LIM. Based on the
venficabon results, a subset of draft tokens that preserves the same distrbunon as the target 11M us
accepted as the final output
Leviathan et al (2023) show that the practical performance of speculanve sampling is highly re.
lated to two factors: the decoding cost of the draft model and its alignment with the target 11M.
‘To develop efficient draft models that are well-aligned with the target LLM, previous works pro-
pose to leverage the target L1_M"s contextual information (Xiao et al., 2024, La et al, 2024b.¢, Du
ct al, 2024), For instance, EAGLE (Li et al, 2024b;c) employs previous hidden states of the target
LLM as the draft model's input features. However, these approaches introduce inconsistent context
between training and decoding, as illustrated in Figure 2. Dunng training, the draft model always
has access to the target LILM's hidden states in previous timesteps. However, duning decoding, the
draft model cannot access the target LIM's hidden states for unverified limesteps, resulting in a con.
text misalignment between training and decoding This issue can be viewed as a form of exposure
bias (Bengwo et al, 2015; Wang & Senanch, 2020) at the feature level in speculative sampling.
Another discrepancy 1s also observed between the objectives of the training and decoding stages.
Dunog the decoding stage. the objective of the draft model 1s to propose tokens that the target 1M.
is likely to assign high probabilines to (Li et al, 2024e, Miao et al, 2024, Sun et al. 2024) In
this scenario, the draft model should focus more on recalling the desired tokens, while the specific
order of these tokens can be somewhat de-emphasized. Moreover, most 11M applications perform

HASS follows a context alignment schema that aligns traming and decoding on their contexts. In
particular, HASS divides the traning procedure into n steps, enabling the draft model to utilize
contextual features consistent with those in the decoding stage. The procedure is outlined as follows:
© The first step murtors the traning stage of EAGLE. At timestep #4 1, the draft model takes
the target model's feature f{" as input and produces the draft feature (2) In this step, the
afflenbon mask remains as the onginal causal mask without any modificaon.
© In the second step, features from the first step are incorporated. Kor instance, 19 the self
aftention mechanism al timestep t+ 1, /,7"" ts used to calculate the current query. Keys
and values are dered from 0) @ f{°'), where @ denotes concatenation and {includes
features from Umesteps earlier thant The atteation mask 1s adjusted to ensure that the
previous feature seen by f("') is always "|, as shown in the “HASS Training Step 2° part
of Figure 3
© For step ) > 3, the feature from the previous step f."!~'! 1s unlized to calculate the query
at timestep t + 1, while keys and values are generated by f 2 B/G. BL
It takes ni times the training overhead of EAGLE while maintaining the same decoding overhead.
We empincally demonstrate that the acceleranon effect converges with a small n so that the training
of HASS 1s cost-efficient

After Musk's acquisition of Twitter, many people I respect and follow moved to Bluesky. I
created an account there and made an honest attempt of making it my primary platform. Sadly,
I found Bluesky to be surprisingly hostile towards AI content. There is an almost religious
resistance to Al on there, at least in whatever corner of the platform I ended up in.

why I find them so helpful.

programmatic experience. This is strictly about how I use Al as a “techy consumer”.

should be dealing with this problem. Particularly on Bluesky a lot of the negativity towards Al is
related to watering down of copyrights and human creation. I don't know the answers to these
things, but I think we need to have a productive dialog here rather than wishing for the
technology to go away.

In addition to general supportive therapy and mechanical treatment of the respiratory system,
a number of drugs are widely used in clinical management, such as angiotensin-converting
enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs). ACEls reduce Ang II
production by inhibiting ACE, and ARBs block the AT1R [11]. These drugs counteract the
cytokine storm of SARS-CoV-2 and lung injury, and are also useful in treating comorbidities in
patients with COVID-19 [12,13]. However, the use of these medications elevates
transmembrane ACE2, thus increasing ACE2 expression in the presence of SARS-CoV-2. This
leads to an increase in viral entry and replication in the body [14,15,16,17]. A controversial
question was proposed, asking whether we should increase ACE2 levels in tissues, focus on
suppressing the inflammatory response and treating comorbidities, or promote a decrease in
ACE2 levels in tissues to reduce viral entry and replication.

In addition to general supportive therapy and mechanical treatment of the respiratory system,
a number of drugs are widely used in clinical management, such as angiotensin-converting
enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs). ACEls reduce Ang II
production by inhibiting ACE, and ARBs block the AT1R [11]. These drugs counteract the
cytokine storm of SARS-CoV-2 and lung injury, and are also useful in treating comorbidities in
patients with COVID-19 [12,13]. However, the use of these medications elevates
transmembrane ACE2, thus increasing ACE2 expression in the presence of SARS-CoV-2. This
leads to an increase in viral entry and replication in the body [14,15,16,17]. A controversial
question was proposed, asking whether we should increase ACE2 levels in tissues, focus on
suppressing the inflammatory response and treating comorbidities, or promote a decrease in
ACE2 levels in tissues to reduce viral entry and replication.

and/or prototypes that advance the state-of-the-art of computer science
and engineering, as well as general scientific knowledge.

Sisters, I won’t allow anyone to not have tried Popeyes’ black pepper chicken tenderloin! +I
finally got it today, and it was so amazing that I wanted to scream! “Although you need to wait
for it to be made, the taste is definitely worth the price. It is completely an upgraded version of
the grilled tenderloin on the street stalls in childhood! The skin is not coated with powder, but
directly covered with super flavorful barbecue ingredients, and the aroma is overwhelming! 4It
is slightly spicy with a smoky feeling, and the aftertaste is salty and herbal. It is really layered!
What touched me most was the texture of the meat! It was super tender when I took a bite, and
there was no feeling of dry chicken breast at all. The full gravy filled my mouth, and the sense
of happiness burst instantly! \n\nThe point is sisters! It is still low in calories! It is a complete
artifact to relieve your cravings during the fat loss period. You are not afraid of getting fat and can
satisfy your desire for meat! *Paired with cocktail sauce or honey mustard sauce, it is directly
open, and your taste buds are spoiled! ®\n\nLadies, here comes something even better! Popeyes
has a limited-time promotion for the past two weeks: 12 pieces of black pepper chicken fillet for
$10! + On average, it’s less than $1 per piece, what kind of price/performance ratio is this? ! “It’s
a blessing for busy girls, and sisters who want to eat meat but don’t want to eat dirt m** ~~ for
it’\n\nRecommendation index: (full score!) \nLadies, don’t hesitate, all yo) see." %
fat loss and happiness is this black pepper chicken fillet!

We are often asked what is the potential bearish case for gold? Intense investor de-
risking was one of the main bearish risks we have cited previously. Though gold’s sharp
bounce back to new record highs following the early-April Liberation day broad de-
risking illustrates the power of physical dip-buyers, including central banks, to hold the
floor even as investor length gets recycled out. Positioning will continue to get stretched
at times though we don’t think it is a structurally bearish risk in gold. More structurally,
an unexpected drop off in central bank demand remains the biggest fundamental risk, as
does the tail risk of some central banks with large holdings selling amid higher prices.
From a macro perspective, a rapid succession of bilateral trade deals, crucially,
including B agreg

More so, the issue TOW be exposed to a
precious metal with a sizeable industrial demand component given the trade and growth
uncertainties that are likely to continue to swirl in the coming months. As such, we think
the primary precious focus is going to continue to be more wholly centered on gold in
the coming quarter. In our view, the window for silver’s stronger catch up to gold begins
to open more fully when we see more stability in the outlook for other industrial metals
prices later this year. Overall, we have made relatively minor changes to our 2025 silver
forecasts, calling for a full year average of ~$35/oz with prices rising sharply in 2H25
towards $39/oz by year-end, on the way to a 2026 average of ~$43/oz.

We are often asked what is the potential bearish case for gold? Intense investor de-
risking was one of the main bearish risks we have cited previously. Though gold’s sharp
bounce back to new record highs following the early-April Liberation day broad de-
risking illustrates the power of physical dip-buyers, including central banks, to hold the
floor even as investor length gets recycled out. Positioning will continue to get stretched
at umes though we don’t think it is a structurally bearish nsk in gold. More structurally,
an unexpected drop off in central bank demand remains the biggest fundamental risk, as
does the tail risk of some central banks with large holdings selling amid higher prices
From a macro perspective, a rapid succession of bilateral trade deals, crucially,
including China agreed to in short order could definitely hit gold as recession
probabilities are walked back, though we still think trade and policy uncertainty could
remain extremely elevated and don’t necessarily view this as a sea change for the trend
in gold demand. In our view, more materially bearish would be a scenario where US
economic growth remains extremely resilient to tariffs allowing the Fed to tum much
more proactive in fighting inflation nsks, prompting markets to price in hikes even
before worrying inflation actually arrives. We sull think this is a far stretch from our
base case at the moment, but would spark a sharp and sustained investor rotation out of
gold

Silver’s catch-up likely to come over 2H25. Silver's sharper fall and slower recovery
vis a vis gold over April mtd has rebased the gold-to-silver ratio from ~90 to over 100
Cuts to forecasted economic growth, industrial activity and concerns around continued
solar demand growth in China weigh on forward looking silver demand fundamentals
Nonetheless, we stll see a silver market remaining in deficit over this year and next
More so, the issue for silver in the near-term is investor's appetite to be exposed to a
precious metal with a sizeable industrial demand component given the trade and growth
uncertainties that are likely to continue to swirl in the coming months. As such, we think
the primary precious focus is going to continue to be more wholly centered on gold in
the coming quarter. In our view, the window for silver’s stronger catch up to gold begins
to open more fully when we see more stability in the outlook for other industrial metals
prices later this year. Overall, we have made relatively minor changes to our 2025 silver
forecasts, calling for a full year average of ~$35/oz with prices rising sharply in 2H25
towards $39/0z by year-end, on the way to a 2026 average of ~$43/0z

We are often asked what is the potential bearish case for gold? Intense investor de-
risking was one of the main bearish risks we have cited previously. Though gold’s sharp
bounce back to new record highs following the early-April Liberation day broad de-
risking illustrates the power of physical dip-buyers, including central banks, to hold the
floor even as investor length gets recycled out. Positioning will continue to get stretched
at umes though we don’t think it is a structurally bearish nsk in gold. More structurally,
an unexpected drop off in central bank demand remains the biggest fundamental risk, as
does the tail risk of some central banks with large holdings selling amid higher prices
From a macro perspective, a rapid succession of bilateral trade deals, crucially,
including China agreed to in short order could definitely hit gold as recession
probabilities are walked back, though we still think trade and policy uncertainty could
remain extremely elevated and don’t necessarily view this as a sea change for the trend
in gold demand. In our view, more materially bearish would be a scenario where US
economic growth remains extremely resilient to tariffs allowing the Fed to tum much
more proactive in fighting inflation nsks, prompting markets to price in hikes even
before worrying inflation actually arrives. We sull think this is a far stretch from our
base case at the moment, but would spark a sharp and sustained investor rotation out of
gold

Silver’s catch-up likely to come over 2H25. Silver's sharper fall and slower recovery
vis a vis gold over April mtd has rebased the gold-to-silver ratio from ~90 to over 100
Cuts to forecasted economic growth, industrial activity and concerns around continued
solar demand growth in China weigh on forward looking silver demand fundamentals
Nonetheless, we stll see a silver market remaining in deficit over this year and next
More so, the issue for silver in the near-term is investor's appetite to be exposed to a
precious metal with a sizeable industrial demand component given the trade and growth
uncertainties that are likely to continue to swirl in the coming months. As such, we think
the primary precious focus is going to continue to be more wholly centered on gold in
the coming quarter. In our view, the window for silver’s stronger catch up to gold begins
to open more fully when we see more stability in the outlook for other industrial metals
prices later this year. Overall, we have made relatively minor changes to our 2025 silver
forecasts, calling for a full year average of ~$35/oz with prices rising sharply in 2H25
towards $39/0z by year-end, on the way to a 2026 average of ~$43/0z

756 BM Foreign Language Teaching and Research (bimonthly) Vol 56 No 2
Abstracts of papers in this issue

Large language models for Contrastive Linguistics (p_ 163)
QIN Hongwu (School of Foreign Languages, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, China)
ZHOU Xia (College of Chinese Language and Literature, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, China)

This study examines emerging opportunities and trends in the field of Contrastive Linguistics
driven by the advent of large language models (LLMs) We argue that the semantic intelligence of
LLMs offers novel possibilities for establishing tertium comparationts (TC), enabling objective
and measurable comparisons that were previously difficult to attain, surpassing the limitations
of traditional methods rooted in translational relations. This advancement has led to the creation
of high-quality knowledge resources that facilitate multi-level and multidimensional contrastive
analyses. This study highlights how the qualitative analysis results generated by LLMs are
transformed into quantitative data, empowering more mixed-method research The study suggests
that LILMs excel in multilingual and multi-level knowledge retrieval, and collaboration between
LLMs and researchers 1s imperative and holds immense potential for various research applications
On semantic model construction of universal quantifications in English and Chinese (p_ 177)
ZHOU Yong (College of International Studies, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225127, China)

The cross-linguistec differences in universal quantification, a traditional topic in formal
semantics, have been extensively studied After examining the criterion of defining universal
quantification and the linguistic data between English and Chinese, it is argued that 1) unlike
the compactness of English universal quantifications, the corresponding ones in Chinese exhibit
the diversified one-to-many distribution, which is usually restricted by the event domain, 2) the
frequent occurrence of dow in Chinese universal quantification, on a par with intensification use of
English universal quantifier like ail, ts inherently an intensifier, eventually, 3) a unified semantic
model of universal quantifications in English and Chinese, relying on the tripartite structure of
quantification, 1s proposed by combining event quantification with individual quantification, which
could not only elucidate the compositionality of the structure, but also address the similarities and
differences between English and Chinese, further highlighting the typological significance of the
study
A study of English irrealis super construction from the perspective of Cognitive Linguistics (p_ 189)
ZHONG Shuneng & CHEN Shigi (School of Foreign Languages, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou

$10640, China)

Based on Construction Grammar, this paper delves into the super construction which
uniformly governs the English irrealis category It is revealed that the super construction underlying
the English irrealis category manifests itself in “if irregular event A, then irregular event B,” the
syntactic form of which manifests as the abnormal change of the head, and 1s equipped with a
continuum from negation to irealis. Nevertheless, as an event schema, the super construction
goveming the English irrealis category portrays a dynamic process projected from Condition A to
Result B. This paper concludes that the new construct of super construction possesses explanatory
power and can be used to elucidate the relationship between several grammatical constructions

756 BM Foreign Language Teaching and Research (bimonthly) Vol 56 No 2
Abstracts of papers in this issue

Large language models for Contrastive Linguistics (p_ 163)
QIN Hongwu (School of Foreign Languages, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, China)
ZHOU Xia (College of Chinese Language and Literature, Qufu Normal University, Qufu 273165, China)

This study examines emerging opportunities and trends in the field of Contrastive Linguistics
driven by the advent of large language models (LLMs) We argue that the semantic intelligence of
LLMs offers novel possibilities for establishing tertium comparationts (TC), enabling objective
and measurable comparisons that were previously difficult to attain, surpassing the limitations
of traditional methods rooted in translational relations. This advancement has led to the creation
of high-quality knowledge resources that facilitate multi-level and multidimensional contrastive
analyses. This study highlights how the qualitative analysis results generated by LLMs are
transformed into quantitative data, empowering more mixed-method research The study suggests
that LILMs excel in multilingual and multi-level knowledge retrieval, and collaboration between
LLMs and researchers 1s imperative and holds immense potential for various research applications
On semantic model construction of universal quantifications in English and Chinese (p_ 177)
ZHOU Yong (College of International Studies, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225127, China)

The cross-linguistec differences in universal quantification, a traditional topic in formal
semantics, have been extensively studied After examining the criterion of defining universal
quantification and the linguistic data between English and Chinese, it is argued that 1) unlike
the compactness of English universal quantifications, the corresponding ones in Chinese exhibit
the diversified one-to-many distribution, which is usually restricted by the event domain, 2) the
frequent occurrence of dow in Chinese universal quantification, on a par with intensification use of
English universal quantifier like ail, ts inherently an intensifier, eventually, 3) a unified semantic
model of universal quantifications in English and Chinese, relying on the tripartite structure of
quantification, 1s proposed by combining event quantification with individual quantification, which
could not only elucidate the compositionality of the structure, but also address the similarities and
differences between English and Chinese, further highlighting the typological significance of the
study
A study of English irrealis super construction from the perspective of Cognitive Linguistics (p_ 189)
ZHONG Shuneng & CHEN Shigi (School of Foreign Languages, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou

$10640, China)

Based on Construction Grammar, this paper delves into the super construction which
uniformly governs the English irrealis category It is revealed that the super construction underlying
the English irrealis category manifests itself in “if irregular event A, then irregular event B,” the
syntactic form of which manifests as the abnormal change of the head, and 1s equipped with a
continuum from negation to irealis. Nevertheless, as an event schema, the super construction
goveming the English irrealis category portrays a dynamic process projected from Condition A to
Result B. This paper concludes that the new construct of super construction possesses explanatory
power and can be used to elucidate the relationship between several grammatical constructions
